awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Control of Columella Root Cap Cell Loosening and Release in Arabidopsis
awd_abstract_narration:
Part I, Non-technical:
Roots are vital for crop health and productivity because they provide water and nutrient uptake, and stability in the soil. Understanding how they function is critical to a sustainable food supply. At the tip of the root is the root cap, a tissue that helps guide the root through soil and protects the root from soil stresses. Cells of the root cap are continually produced and released into the surrounding soil. Released cells help repel pathogenic microbes from the root and are an important part of plant defense. The features governing root cap cell release are currently unknown. This knowledge is necessary to fully understand root function and to develop plants with increased productivity. This project will use the model plant Arabidopsis to identify the essential genes and characteristics that govern root cap cell release. It will provide training to undergraduates, graduate students and a postdoctoral scientist and will engage the local community in plant root biology. The knowledge generated will enhance our ability to develop plants with increased productivity.

Part II, Technical:
Roots are pivotal to plant health and crop productivity. The root cap provides essential functions for the whole root, and is critical to root growth and health. Root cap functionality is dependent on a stable root cap size. In the columella root cap, located at the tip of the root, size is maintained by a balance between root cap cell release and columella cell production. The mechanism underlying root cap cell release is not well understood, yet this process has crucial implications for root protection from environmental stress. This project will identify the mechanism through which the transcription factor, NIN-LIKE PROTEIN 7 (NLP7), controls root cap cell release and will identify additional regulators of root cap development in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana. The project's research goals are to: 1) determine how the subcellular and tissue localization of NLP7 alters root cap cell release and 2) identify NLP7-regulated genes and networks that function in root cap cell release. This work will be instrumental for understanding the genes that govern root cap development and will lead to crops with enhanced growth and productivity, especially in environments with pathogenic soil microbes. This project will train a postdoctoral student, graduate student and undergraduates. Outreach will be targeted toward the local community to increase their knowledge and engagement of plant science through summer workshops that focus on understanding plant root biology and its importance to crop productivity.

por.por_cntn:
The root cap is a small tissue at the tip of the root that is essential for plant health. This tissue functions to sense gravity and water and protect the root meristem from external stress. The root cap maintains a constant size by coordinating root cap cell production with release of the last layer of cells. The constant size is necessary for the root cap to perform its functions. In this grant we investigated the role of the transcription factor NIN-LIKE PROTEIN 7 (NLP7) in regulating root cap development in Arabidopsis thaliana. NLP7 has been well characterized for its role in nitrate signaling. Our previous work revealed a role for NLP7 in regulating release of the last layer of root cap cells. Here, we found that NLP7 regulates release of the last layer of the root cap through auxin pathways.

 

Because NLP7 is well known for its role in nitrate signaling, we investigated the impact of low nitrate conditions on root cap cell release in wild type Arabidopsis. Compared to nitrate complete conditions, nitrate-free conditions led to increased release of root cap cells as single cells in wild type plants. In the loss-of-function nlp7-1 mutant, root cap cell release was not significantly different between nitrate-free and complete conditions.

 

Recent work showed that in wild type plants auxin responses decrease in the last layer of the root cap in plants older than 5 days, and an auxin minimum is required for root cap cell release. In contrast, we found that nlp7 does not have an auxin minimum in the last layer of the root cap. Additional lines of evidence suggested that auxin pathways and NLP7 might interact during root cap cell release. For example, data from our laboratory suggested that the transcription factor Auxin Response Factor 8 (ARF8) is a putative upstream regulator of NLP7, and we found that NLP7 expression is induced by auxin. We hypothesized that NLP7 regulates root cap cell release through auxin pathways.

 

The lack of an auxin minimum in the nlp7 mutant could be due to altered expression of PIN and PILs (PIN-LIKES) auxin transporters. PIN3, PIN7, and PILS3 have been previously described as direct targets downstream of NLP7. We found that PIN7 and PILS3 auxin transporters had reduced protein expression in nlp7 compared to wild type plants. Our data suggest that the reduced expression of auxin transporters in nlp7 prevents an auxin minima from forming in the separating root cap layer. This in turn leads to altered root cap cell release. We also found that transcription factors that regulate auxin pathways in the root, including WOX5, PLT1 and PLT2, have decreased expression in nlp7. NLP7 promotes the differentiation of Columella Stem Cells (CSCs) and has increased QC divisions compared to wild type Col-0. Because auxin functions in the regulation of CSC division, we hypothesize that the altered CSC division is due to the altered auxin pathways in the nlp7 mutant.  Together our data suggest that the NLP7 impacts both root cap cell release and columella stem cell divisions by impacting auxin transport and homeostasis.  Changes to auxin transport lead to alterations in auxin minima in the last layer of the root cap, which likely contribute to the single cell root cap release phenotype in the nlp7 mutant.

 

We identified 11 putative upstream regulators of NLP7 in a Yeast 1-Hybrid screen, including ARF8 and DREB2A. DREB2A functions in water stress responses and the nlp7 mutant is drought tolerant.  NLP7 expression decreased 8 days after withholding water. Untargeted metabolite analysis revealed that osmoprotectant metabolites are upregulated in nlp7 compared to wild type. Recent genome wide transcription factor binding studies suggest that DREB2A is also a target of NLP7, suggesting the two proteins may operate in a feedback loop. We confirmed that expression of DREB2A is altered in the nlp7 mutant in water stress conditions. Several genes that function in drought responses are mis-regulated in nlp7. nlp7 had higher water use efficiency in a single leaf compared to wild type when exposed to ABA but not under standard (no ABA) conditions. This higher WUE during exposure to stress could contribute to the increased drought tolerance of nlp7.

 

Together our results highlight two new functions for NLP7-  one in regulating auxin pathways for root cap development, and the other for regulating drought tolerance. Given its many roles in development and stress responses, manipulating NLP7 expression may be important for plant health and production.

 

This grant trained a postdoc, graduate student and multiple undergraduates in plant development. As part of the broader impacts, we developed a citizen science summer program in which local citizens came to Purdue to learn about microbiology. We also went to an underrepresented minority-serving community center in Indianapolis for a 7 week summer program to teach 7th - 12th graders about plant biology.
